issues.text: Whether in law, if there is an obligation on the employer to pay a certain bonus, the Excess Profits Tax Officer is bound to allow it as a deduction and is precluded from exercising his discretion under rule 12(1) of the First Schedule of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in law, if there is an obligation on the employer to any a certain bonus, the Excess Profits Tax Officer is bound to allow it as a deduction and is precluded from exercising his discretion under rule 10 1  of the First Schedule of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

issues.text: If the answer to the first question is in the affirmative, whether on a true construction of the agreement between the assessee and its employees and the Provident Fund Rules, the assessee company is under obligation to pay the bonus without deducting the excess profits tax.

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to the first question is in the formative whether on a true companystruction of the agreement between the assessee and its employees and the provident Fund Rules, the assessee companypany is under obligation to pay the bonus without deducting the excess profits tax.

precedents.citation: Walchand Co. Ltd. v. Hindustan companystruction Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Excess profits Tax Officer was rested on a decision of the Bombay High companyrt reported in Walchand Co. Ltd. v. Hindustan companystruction Co. Ltd., excess profits tax was analysed by Chagla, C.J. Having quoted from the judgment of Chalga, C.J. J., the Excess Profits Tax Officer set down rule 12 of first Schedule of the Excess profits Tax Act, and observed as follows In the light of the observations of the Chief Justice in the case of Walchand Co. Ltd. quoted above the payments of bonuses on the basis of net profits as per balance sheet without deducting excess profits tax is clearly both unreasonable and unnecessary with in the meaning of rule 12 of Schedule I of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Walchand Co Ltd v Hindustan Construction Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: payments of bonuses on the basis of net profits as per balance sheet without deducting excess profits tax is clearly both unreasonable and unnecessary within the meaning of rule 12 of Schedule I of the Act

Ltd. v. G.B. Ollivant, Ltd.,  1945  13 ITR  Sup.  23. He also referred to three decisions of the Indian High Courts in which a similar view was taken, viz., N.M. Rayaloo Iyer and Sons v.
